revised_title: The Elasticity of Spiders: Water-Induced Mobility in Spider Webs
tldr: The elasticity of spiders' webs is due to water-induced mobility at a molecular level. Researchers used 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (nmr) spectroscopy to demonstrate that water retention plays a significant role in the viscid coating of capture threads, and the extra elasticity of capture threads results from water-induced mobility at a molecular level. The study also found that the organization and composition of structural and capture threads are different, even in the absence of coating, and that glycoproteins may have a more important presence and structural role than previously realized.
